aws::graph::propositions: # Cessna 177RG Accident During Aborted Landing at Litchfield Municipal Airport
A Cessna 177RG aircraft with registration N1564H experienced a loss of control on ground during landing.
The loss of control on ground was the defining event of the accident.
The aircraft experienced loss of control in flight during initial climb.
The aircraft experienced an uncontrolled descent.
The aircraft collided with terrain/objects (non-CFIT).
The accident occurred on August 11, 2012, at 1150 central daylight time.
The Cessna 177RG impacted terrain during initial climb from an aborted landing on runway 36.
The accident occurred at Litchfield Municipal Airport (3LF) in Litchfield, Illinois.
The private pilot received minor injuries.
The airplane sustained substantial damage to the fuselage.
The airplane was registered to the pilot.
The airplane was operated by the pilot.
The flight was operated under the provisions of 14 Code of Federal Regulations Part 91.
The flight was classified as a personal flight.
Visual meteorological conditions prevailed during the flight.
A flight plan had not been filed for the flight.
The flight departed from St. Louis Regional Airport in Alton, Illinois.
The flight departed at approximately 1130 central daylight time.
The flight's destination was Litchfield Municipal Airport (3LF).
During landing, the airplane veered to the left.
The airplane headed toward airport lighting equipment after veering left.
The pilot performed an aborted landing.
During the initial climb following the aborted landing, the airplane stalled.
The airplane impacted trees after stalling.
The airplane landed on a bean field after impacting trees.
The pilot reported no mechanical malfunction or failure with the airplane at the time of the accident.
The pilot recommended better control upon landing to prevent similar accidents.
The pilot recommended recognition of crosswind conditions to prevent similar accidents.

text:
# Factual Information

## History of Flight

| Event | Description |
| --- | --- |
| Landing-aborted after touchdown | Loss of control on ground (Defining event) |
| Initial climb | Loss of control in flight |
| Uncontrolled descent | Collision with terr/obj (non-CFIT) |

On August 11, 2012, at 1150 central daylight time, a Cessna 177RG, N1564H, impacted terrain during initial climb from an aborted landing on runway 36 at Litchfield Municipal Airport (3LF), Litchfield, Illinois. The private pilot received minor injuries. The airplane sustained substantial damage to the fuselage. The airplane was registered to and operated by the pilot under the provisions of 14 Code of Federal Regulations Part 91 as a personal flight. Visual meteorological conditions prevailed and a flight plan had not been filed for the flight that departed from St. Louis Regional Airport, Alton, Illinois, about 1130 and was en route to 3LF.

The pilot stated that during landing, the airplane veered to the left and headed toward airport lighting equipment. The pilot performed an aborted landing, and during the initial climb, the airplane stalled and impacted trees. The airplane then landed on a bean field.

The pilot reported that there was no mechanical malfunction/failure with the airplane at the time of the accident.

The pilot's recommendation of how the accident could have been prevented was, "Better control upon landing [and] recognition of crosswind conditions."
